In early versions of the [[legendarium]], '''''Fôs' Almir''''' (the '''Bath of Flame'''),<ref name=LT2II/> also called '''''Faskalan''''', '''''Faskala-númen''''' (the '''Bath of the Setting Sun''') and '''''Tanyasalpë''''' (the bowl of fire),<ref name=LT1/> was a purifying bath.<ref name=LT2II>{{LT2|II}}, pp. 115-6</ref><ref name=LT2IIn>{{LT2|IIn}}, p. 138 (§2)</ref>

The bath was fashioned as a great basin with golden floor and walls of polished bronze. An "arcade of golden pillars topped with fires engirdled it" and [[Yavanna]] "set a great and nameless [[Magic|spell]] around it, so that therein was poured the most of the waters of the fruit of the noon and it became a bath of fire".<ref name=LT1>{{LT1|VIII}}, p. 187</ref>

It was told that [[Urwendi]] and her maidens, before the rising of the [[Sun]], entered into Faskalan.<ref name="LT1Sun">{{LT1|VIII}}, p. 118</ref> [[Túrin|Turambar]] and [[Nienor|Nienóri]] entered Faskalan after their death.<ref name=LT2II/><ref name=LT2IIn/>
== Etymology ==
''Fôs' Almir'' is a [[Gnomish]] name, meaning "Galmir's bath, i.e. [[Sun]]'s bath".<ref name=PE11>{{PE|11}}, p. 12</ref>

''Tanyasalpë'' is a [[Qenya]] name, containing ''tanya'' ("fire")<ref>{{PE|15}}, p. 9 (note 6)</ref> and ''salpa'' "bowl".<ref>{{LT2|Appendix}}, p. 266</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
A rejected name used in earlier texts for the bath was '''''Fauri'''''.<ref name=LT2IIn/>

''Fôs' Almir'' appears to also have been used by [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] as a name for the [[Belegaer|Western Sea]].<ref name=PE11/>
